comments:
Build 20020412
Linux-motif

While debugging, I clicked on a stack frame which opened
ASTInstructionCompiler.java. In the method "public boolean visit(ArrayType
node)" I put my cursor in the call to "getElementType()" on the line which
reads: "ITypeBinding typeBinding= node.getElementType().resolveBinding();"

When I hit F3, I get an internal error dialog with the following detail.

looks OK to me. Moving to Platform UI.

Here's another stack trace that illustrates the same problem. This one occurred
when an editor was opening for a stack trace.

It should be noted that I see these problems "all the time."

Randy, have you seen this one before?

You mentioned that it happens all the time. 
Is it still happening in the latest build 20020423?

Note that the second stack trace is pretty much the same as the trace I filed as
14263. If the first and second stack trace's in this report represent the same
bug (I'm not qualified to make the call), 14263 should be closed as a dup.

Another stack trace for your viewing pleasure.

Perhaps some excruciating detail will help.

I had approx. 10 editors open the last five editor's tabs were visible in the
view. The left arrow was enabled (more editors to the left), the right was
disabled (no more editors to the right). I was in a (dirty) Java editor (the
second editor from the left) on a .java file, with my cursor in a method call. I
hit F3 to open the method declaration, which was in IResource.class. The new
editor opened on the far right, scrolling the others to the left such that my
original editor is now the first editor on the left (still 5 tabs showing). An
internal error dialog pops up with the following stack trace.

If I close IResource.class, it returns me to my original editor (and scrolls the
editors tabs to the right again). If I hit F3 again, I get the internal error
again. I can repeat this ad infinitum. The error happens every time.

Aha! At last, a simple test case! (sorry about all the email)

1. Open a .java file
2. Select something in the .java file and hit F3 such that the opened file is a
.class file
3. Blamo.

Do you have the Preferences>Workbench>Close Editors Automatically option 
turned on?
Should consider as patch for M5 stream.

During the opening of the .class file editor, we have to remove 4 toolbar 
items from the .java editor.
Disposing the first tool item is causing an activation callback which leads to 
a re-entry in to the toolbar update code.
This is likely an SWT bug related to the fact that on linux-motif toolitems 
are real widgets. While this is being investigated I have released a fix to UI 
code to prevent the exception from occuring.
*** Bug 10487 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
No longer getting activation callback when disposing the tool item.
